Title:
Phylogenomics of the Paraneoptera (Hemiptera, Psocodea,
Thysanoptera) using next-generation transcriptomics
Abstract:
Insects in the Paraneoptera encompass a large diversity of
species spanning three orders of insects (Hemiptera, Thysanoptera and
Psocodea). These insects possess a broad range of feeding strategies and
thus have a wide array of highly adaptive mouthparts. A lack of resolved
phylogenetic relationships within this group currently impedes our
understanding of the diversification of this lineage. Here we use
phylogenomic data to study the evolution of the Hemipteroid assemblage
and resolve several conflicts among previous phylogenetic hypotheses. We
generated novel transcriptome data for eleven species, and combined
these with publically available complete proteomes and transcriptomes
for seventeen additional key taxa. Analysis with maximum likelihood and
Bayesian inference of three data sets that differ in taxon and gene
representation (maxsp: 28 taxa, 62 genes and 9,088 amino acid positions,
45% missing data; newseqsp: 18 taxa, 115 genes and 16,808 amino acid
positions, 41% missing data; maxgen: 9 taxa, 364 genes and 58,874 amino
acid positions, 20% missing data) gave congruent results. We place the
Thysanoptera as sister to Hemiptera, find the Cicadomorpha
(=Clypeorrhyncha) and Fulguromorpha (=Archaeorrhyncha) monophyletic and
a monophyletic Auchenorrhyncha sister to the Heteroptera. The analyses
show strong support for superfamily relationships within the
Sternorrhyncha (Psylloidea + (Coccoidea + (Aleyroidea + Aphidoidea)))
and lends further support for the paraphyly of Psocoptera. Calibration
places the origin of the Hemipteroid assemblage during the Carboniferous
(approx 325 MYA) and suggests a rapid radiation of superfamilies in
Auchenorrhyncha compared to Sternorrhyncha.
